creator: owennnn@hotmail.com
text:
The biggest reason to use a prefix when loading a properties file, is to prevent collisions with existing properties of the same name.

However, the behaviour I am seeing is that if there is an existing value for a property also in the file (unprefixed name), that existing value, rather than the value in the properties file, is assigned to the prefixed property.  This is bad!

I've attached a short example ant script that demonstrates the problem.

creator: owennnn@hotmail.com
text:
bugzilla is refusing to allow me to add an attachment to this bug, so I'll paste the ant script to reproduce here:

<project default="showBug">
	<target name="showBug">
		<echo message="mood: Happy" file="my.properties"/>
		<property name="mood" value="Sad"/>
		<property file="my.properties" prefix="my"/>
		<echo message="Expected: mood=Sad, my.mood=Happy"/>
		<echo message="  Actual: mood=${mood}, my.mood=${my.mood}"/>
		<!-- with ant 1.8.1, I get Actual: mood=Sad, my.mood=Sad -->
	</target>
</project>

Yes, this is unfortunate and has already been fixed in svn.
